        <item>
          <title>Sunscreen may prevent skin cancer by 80% </title>
          <link>https://www.thestar.com/life/health_wellness/2016/05/10/sunscreen-may-prevent-skin-cancer-by-80.html</link>
          <guid isPermaLink="false">ecb4edbf-a4a4-4d9c-b1cf-55bb206c7493</guid>
          
          <pubDate>Tue, 10 May 2016 22:26:30 EDT</pubDate>
          <description>
          
          	<img src="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/life/health_wellness/2016/05/10/sunscreen-may-prevent-skin-cancer-by-80/sunscreenjpg.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg"/><br/>Researchers have discovered that sunscreens with SPF 30 reduce the risk of melanoma. 
          
          </description>

          
          
          <author>
            Allie Shah - TRIBUNE NEWS SERVICE</author>
            

       
	            <media:content url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/life/health_wellness/2016/05/10/sunscreen-may-prevent-skin-cancer-by-80/sunscreenjpg.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg" medium="image">
	              <media:thumbnail url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/life/health_wellness/2016/05/10/sunscreen-may-prevent-skin-cancer-by-80/sunscreenjpg.jpg.size.xsmall.original.jpg"></media:thumbnail>
	              <media:description>Researchers have found finds SPF-30 sunscreens can significantly prevent the development of skin cancer in mice.</media:description>
	              <media:credit role="author">Handout</media:credit>
	              
	              <media:credit role="owner">TNS</media:credit>
	              
	            </media:content>
	            

        
        

        
        

        
        
        </item>
    
        <item>
          <title>Five questions about stem-cell transplants in Ontario</title>
          <link>https://www.thestar.com/life/health_wellness/2016/05/10/five-questions-about-stem-cell-transplants-in-ontario.html</link>
          <guid isPermaLink="false">a9b59d28-2a8f-4163-b183-1cbc237c2ae3</guid>
          
          <pubDate>Tue, 10 May 2016 19:45:32 EDT</pubDate>
          <description>
          
          	<img src="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/life/health_wellness/2016/05/10/five-questions-about-stem-cell-transplants-in-ontario/eric-hoskins.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg"/><br/>Ontario Health Minister Eric Hoskins has pledged to fix a fatally flawed system for providing allogeneic stem-cell transplants. But critical questions haven’t been answered.
          
          </description>

          
          
          <author>
            Diana Zlomislic - News reporter</author>
            

       
	            <media:content url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/life/health_wellness/2016/05/10/five-questions-about-stem-cell-transplants-in-ontario/eric-hoskins.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg" medium="image">
	              <media:thumbnail url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/life/health_wellness/2016/05/10/five-questions-about-stem-cell-transplants-in-ontario/eric-hoskins.jpg.size.xsmall.original.jpg"></media:thumbnail>
	              <media:description>Health Minister Eric Hoskins has promised to fix Ontaro's broken system for delivering allogeneic (unrelated donor) stem-cell transplants, a cutting edge but time-consuming treatment that can save the lives of many cancer and blood-disorder patients.</media:description>
	              <media:credit role="author">ANDREW FRANCIS WALLACE</media:credit>
	              
	              <media:credit role="owner">TORONTO STAR</media:credit>
	              
	            </media:content>
	            

        
        

        
        

        
        
        </item>
    
        <item>
          <title>Drinking diet soda while pregnant impacts infant’s weight, study suggests</title>
          <link>https://www.thestar.com/life/health_wellness/nutrition/2016/05/09/drinking-diet-soda-while-pregnant-impacts-infants-weight-study-suggests.html</link>
          <guid isPermaLink="false">71018d0c-2858-4b2d-b464-f4b22f7ea3b6</guid>
          
          <pubDate>Mon, 9 May 2016 18:18:40 EDT</pubDate>
          <description>
          
          	<img src="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/life/health_wellness/nutrition/2016/05/09/drinking-diet-soda-while-pregnant-impacts-infants-weight-study-suggests/glyxphz3.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg"/><br/>New Canadian study of more than 3,000 moms and infants raises red flags about artificial sweeteners.
          
          </description>

          
          
          <author>
            Lauren Pelley - Staff Reporter</author>
            

       
	            <media:content url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/life/health_wellness/nutrition/2016/05/09/drinking-diet-soda-while-pregnant-impacts-infants-weight-study-suggests/glyxphz3.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg" medium="image">
	              <media:thumbnail url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/life/health_wellness/nutrition/2016/05/09/drinking-diet-soda-while-pregnant-impacts-infants-weight-study-suggests/glyxphz3.jpg.size.xsmall.original.jpg"></media:thumbnail>
	              <media:description>New Canadian study of more than 3,000 moms looks into the consumption of  artificially sweetened beverages during pregnancy and the risk of having overweight infants.
</media:description>
	              <media:credit role="author"></media:credit>
	              
	              <media:credit role="owner"></media:credit>
	              
	            </media:content>
	            

        
        

        
        

        
        
        </item>
    
        <item>
          <title>Get fit doing 2-arm kettlebell swings</title>
          <link>https://www.thestar.com/life/health_wellness/fitness/2016/05/09/get-fit-doing-2-arm-kettlebell-swings.html</link>
          <guid isPermaLink="false">bc474fcf-2389-41ac-82ca-4ae62fceda49</guid>
          
          <pubDate>Mon, 9 May 2016 13:00:00 EDT</pubDate>
          <description>
          
          	<img src="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/life/health_wellness/fitness/2016/05/09/get-fit-doing-2-arm-kettlebell-swings/move--main-art-step-3-for-web.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg"/><br/>Jennifer Lau shows how to do this easy at-home move that works out your entire core.
          
          </description>

          
          
          <author>
            Lauren Pelley - Staff Reporter</author>
            

       
	            <media:content url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/life/health_wellness/fitness/2016/05/09/get-fit-doing-2-arm-kettlebell-swings/move--main-art-step-3-for-web.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg" medium="image">
	              <media:thumbnail url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/life/health_wellness/fitness/2016/05/09/get-fit-doing-2-arm-kettlebell-swings/move--main-art-step-3-for-web.jpg.size.xsmall.original.jpg"></media:thumbnail>
	              <media:description>Personal trainer and owner of Fit Squad Toronto Jennifer Lau shows off some moves that anyone can do at home with minimal equipment.</media:description>
	              <media:credit role="author">Richard Lautens</media:credit>
	              
	              <media:credit role="owner">Toronto Star</media:credit>
	              
	            </media:content>
	            

        
        

        
        

        
        
        </item>
    
        <item>
          <title>Toronto’s #bodypositive movement is growing</title>
          <link>https://www.thestar.com/life/health_wellness/2016/05/09/torontos-bodypositive-movement-is-growing.html</link>
          <guid isPermaLink="false">cd83eb29-74b3-4115-a3ab-842469588c01</guid>
          
          <pubDate>Mon, 9 May 2016 08:00:00 EDT</pubDate>
          <description>
          
          	<img src="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/life/2016/05/09/torontos-bodypositive-movement-is-growing/karyn-johnson.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg"/><br/>In between all the fitness selfies and healthy meals cluttering social media is a growing thread of body positivity 
          
          </description>

          
          
          <author>
            Katrina Clarke - Staff Reporter</author>
            

       
	            <media:content url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/life/2016/05/09/torontos-bodypositive-movement-is-growing/karyn-johnson.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg" medium="image">
	              <media:thumbnail url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/life/2016/05/09/torontos-bodypositive-movement-is-growing/karyn-johnson.jpg.size.xsmall.original.jpg"></media:thumbnail>
	              <media:description>Karyn Johnson is the creator of the plus size fashion blog "Killer Kurves" and one of Toronto's increasingly recognizable faces in the city's growing body positivity movement.</media:description>
	              <media:credit role="author">Melissa Renwick</media:credit>
	              
	              <media:credit role="owner">Toronto Star</media:credit>
	              
	            </media:content>
	            

        
        

        
        

        
        
        </item>
    
        <item>
          <title>Caregivers shouldn’t be communicating in a different language around a person with dementia</title>
          <link>https://www.thestar.com/life/health_wellness/2016/05/09/caregivers-shouldnt-be-communicating-in-a-different-language-around-a-person-with-dementia.html</link>
          <guid isPermaLink="false">5c5c6add-5a42-4908-8a70-18d944865113</guid>
          
          <pubDate>Mon, 9 May 2016 06:00:00 EDT</pubDate>
          <description>
          
          	<img src="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/life/health_wellness/2016/05/09/caregivers-shouldnt-be-communicating-in-a-different-language-around-a-person-with-dementia/caregiver-sos.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg"/><br/>People with dementia often experience feelings of paranoia which can be exacerbated by their caregivers speaking a language they don’t understand.
          
          </description>

          
          
          <author>
            Nira Rittenberg - Special to the Star</author>
            

       
	            <media:content url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/life/health_wellness/2016/05/09/caregivers-shouldnt-be-communicating-in-a-different-language-around-a-person-with-dementia/caregiver-sos.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg" medium="image">
	              <media:thumbnail url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/life/health_wellness/2016/05/09/caregivers-shouldnt-be-communicating-in-a-different-language-around-a-person-with-dementia/caregiver-sos.jpg.size.xsmall.original.jpg"></media:thumbnail>
	              <media:description>Thos in the early stages of dementia have trouble finding the right words to express themselves. This makes awareness about communication especially important for their caregivers.</media:description>
	              <media:credit role="author"></media:credit>
	              
	              <media:credit role="owner">dreamstine</media:credit>
	              
	            </media:content>
	            

        
        

        
        

        
        
        </item>
    
        <item>
          <title>Test your yoga boat pose in the swimming pool</title>
          <link>https://www.thestar.com/life/health_wellness/Fitness/2016/05/09/test-your-yoga-boat-pose-in-the-swimming-pool.html</link>
          <guid isPermaLink="false">14d587d7-8800-4754-9ac9-636c7a670211</guid>
          
          <pubDate>Mon, 9 May 2016 06:00:00 EDT</pubDate>
          <description>
          
          	<img src="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/life/health_wellness/Fitness/2016/05/09/test-your-yoga-boat-pose-in-the-swimming-pool/boat-1--throw.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg"/><br/>Float your boat pose introduces a fun cardiovascular challenge to a yoga classic.
          
          </description>

          
          
          <author>
            YuMee Chung - Special to the Star</author>
            

       
	            <media:content url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/life/health_wellness/Fitness/2016/05/09/test-your-yoga-boat-pose-in-the-swimming-pool/boat-1--throw.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg" medium="image">
	              <media:thumbnail url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/life/health_wellness/Fitness/2016/05/09/test-your-yoga-boat-pose-in-the-swimming-pool/boat-1--throw.jpg.size.xsmall.original.jpg"></media:thumbnail>
	              <media:description>Try a classic yoga pose in the pool.</media:description>
	              <media:credit role="author">Carlos Osorio</media:credit>
	              
	              <media:credit role="owner">Toronto Star</media:credit>
	              
	            </media:content>
	            

        
        

        
        

        
        
        </item>
    
        <item>
          <title>Doctor’s Notes: Palliative care is not about dying, but about quality of living</title>
          <link>https://www.thestar.com/life/health_wellness/2016/05/09/palliative-care-is-not-about-dying-but-quality-of-living.html</link>
          <guid isPermaLink="false">7c2b6838-0868-4a01-b787-0b63f5862d83</guid>
          
          <pubDate>Mon, 9 May 2016 06:00:00 EDT</pubDate>
          <description>
          
          	<img src="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/life/health_wellness/2016/05/09/palliative-care-is-not-about-dying-but-quality-of-living/doctors-notes2.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg"/><br/>End-of-life care is about more than assisted suicide, and it doesn’t mean giving up or ‘stopping the fight.’
          
          </description>

          
          
          <author>
            Dr. Jeff Myers - University of Toronto</author>
            

       
	            <media:content url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/life/health_wellness/2016/05/09/palliative-care-is-not-about-dying-but-quality-of-living/doctors-notes2.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg" medium="image">
	              <media:thumbnail url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/life/health_wellness/2016/05/09/palliative-care-is-not-about-dying-but-quality-of-living/doctors-notes2.jpg.size.xsmall.original.jpg"></media:thumbnail>
	              <media:description>Evidence suggests that patients who receive specialized palliative care may life longer than those who don't.</media:description>
	              <media:credit role="author"></media:credit>
	              
	              <media:credit role="owner">Dreamstime</media:credit>
	              
	            </media:content>
	            
	            <media:content url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/life/health_wellness/2016/05/09/palliative-care-is-not-about-dying-but-quality-of-living/palliative-care.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg" medium="image">
	              <media:thumbnail url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/life/health_wellness/2016/05/09/palliative-care-is-not-about-dying-but-quality-of-living/palliative-care.jpg.size.xsmall.original.jpg"></media:thumbnail>
	              <media:description>Proper palliative care can protect patients from experiencing unnecessary symptoms and pain.</media:description>
	              <media:credit role="author"></media:credit>
	              
	              <media:credit role="owner">Dreamstime</media:credit>
	              
	            </media:content>
	            

        
        

        
        

        
        
        </item>
    
        <item>
          <title>U.K. and U.S. families sue sperm bank over donor with mental illness</title>
          <link>https://www.thestar.com/life/health_wellness/2016/05/04/uk-and-us-families-sue-sperm-bank-over-donor-with-mental-illness.html</link>
          <guid isPermaLink="false">8ec0cc39-c92f-46f7-9c89-e05eed258bd7</guid>
          
          <pubDate>Wed, 4 May 2016 21:16:09 EDT</pubDate>
          <description>
          
          	<img src="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/life/health_wellness/2016/05/04/uk-and-us-families-sue-sperm-bank-over-donor-with-mental-illness/angie-collins.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg"/><br/>Families allege they were misinformed about their sperm donor who turned out to be mentally ill and have a criminal past. 
          
          </description>

          
          
          <author>
            Theresa Boyle - Health, Ontario</author>
            

       
	            <media:content url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/life/health_wellness/2016/05/04/uk-and-us-families-sue-sperm-bank-over-donor-with-mental-illness/angie-collins.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg" medium="image">
	              <media:thumbnail url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/life/health_wellness/2016/05/04/uk-and-us-families-sue-sperm-bank-over-donor-with-mental-illness/angie-collins.jpg.size.xsmall.original.jpg"></media:thumbnail>
	              <media:description>Angie Collins, of Port Hope, is among those suing U.S.-based sperm bank Xytex.</media:description>
	              <media:credit role="author">Bernard Weil</media:credit>
	              
	              <media:credit role="owner">Toronto Star file photo</media:credit>
	              
	            </media:content>
	            

        
        

        
        

        
        
        </item>
    
        <item>
          <title>Hands-Free Can Opener pose strengthens a major body blind spot: Moves</title>
          <link>https://www.thestar.com/life/health_wellness/2016/05/02/hands-free-can-opener-pose-strengthens-a-major-body-blind-spot-moves.html</link>
          <guid isPermaLink="false">22998f5d-20be-4112-af2f-e220ed224c26</guid>
          
          <pubDate>Mon, 2 May 2016 11:00:00 EDT</pubDate>
          <description>
          
          	<img src="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/life/health_wellness/2016/05/02/hands-free-can-opener-pose-strengthens-a-major-body-blind-spot-moves/can-opener-2.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg"/><br/>Target the psoas, a muscle that connects the lumbar vertebrae to the femur.
          
          </description>

          
          
          <author>
            YuMee Chung - Special to the Star</author>
            

       
	            <media:content url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/life/health_wellness/2016/05/02/hands-free-can-opener-pose-strengthens-a-major-body-blind-spot-moves/can-opener-2.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg" medium="image">
	              <media:thumbnail url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/life/health_wellness/2016/05/02/hands-free-can-opener-pose-strengthens-a-major-body-blind-spot-moves/can-opener-2.jpg.size.xsmall.original.jpg"></media:thumbnail>
	              <media:description>YuMee Chung shows a yoga move called the Hands-Free Can Opener, a good stretch for the psoas muscle.</media:description>
	              <media:credit role="author">Bernard Weil</media:credit>
	              
	              <media:credit role="owner">Toronto Star</media:credit>
	              
	            </media:content>
	            

        
        

        
        

        
        
        </item>
    
        <item>
          <title>Just 60 seconds of intense exercise can boost your fitness level, study finds</title>
          <link>https://www.thestar.com/life/health_wellness/nutrition/2016/05/02/just-60-seconds-of-intense-exercise-can-boost-your-fitness-level-study-finds.html</link>
          <guid isPermaLink="false">34de7461-2bd6-4a16-b6d5-fe87d2f2daf7</guid>
          
          <pubDate>Mon, 2 May 2016 06:30:00 EDT</pubDate>
          <description>
          
          	<img src="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/life/2016/04/28/just-60-seconds-of-intense-exercise-can-boost-your-fitness-level-study-finds/cycling.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg"/><br/>New Canadian research highlights benefits of short-but-intense interval training, compared to traditional exercise
          
          </description>

          
          
          <author>
            Lauren Pelley - Staff Reporter</author>
            

       
	            <media:content url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/life/2016/04/28/just-60-seconds-of-intense-exercise-can-boost-your-fitness-level-study-finds/cycling.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg" medium="image">
	              <media:thumbnail url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/life/2016/04/28/just-60-seconds-of-intense-exercise-can-boost-your-fitness-level-study-finds/cycling.jpg.size.xsmall.original.jpg"></media:thumbnail>
	              <media:description>A McMaster study put groups of men on bicycles three times a week. One group worked in intervals while the other had long continuous sessions.</media:description>
	              <media:credit role="author"></media:credit>
	              
	              <media:credit role="owner">dreamstime</media:credit>
	              
	            </media:content>
	            
	            <media:content url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/life/2016/04/28/just-60-seconds-of-intense-exercise-can-boost-your-fitness-level-study-finds/martin-gibala.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg" medium="image">
	              <media:thumbnail url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/life/2016/04/28/just-60-seconds-of-intense-exercise-can-boost-your-fitness-level-study-finds/martin-gibala.jpg.size.xsmall.original.jpg"></media:thumbnail>
	              <media:description>Martin Gibala, professor of kinesiology at McMaster University and the lead author of the study says both groups improved their cardiovascular fitness and aerobic power.</media:description>
	              <media:credit role="author">JD Howell</media:credit>
	              
	              <media:credit role="owner">McMaster University</media:credit>
	              
	            </media:content>
	            

        
        

        
        

        
        
        </item>
    
        <item>
          <title>Doctor’s Notes: Your mental health can affect your heart health </title>
          <link>https://www.thestar.com/life/health_wellness/2016/05/02/doctors-notes-your-mental-health-can-affect-your-heart-health.html</link>
          <guid isPermaLink="false">6494b94f-1bef-497a-85f0-a6fb6cfd6af1</guid>
          
          <pubDate>Mon, 2 May 2016 06:00:00 EDT</pubDate>
          <description>
          
          	<img src="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/life/health_wellness/2016/05/02/doctors-notes-your-mental-health-can-affect-your-heart-health/weight-gain.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg"/><br/>Conditions related to weight management and cardiovascular health — obesity, diabetes, heart disease — are high among people with mental disorders. 
          
          </description>

          
          
          <author>
            Dr. Valerie Taylor - University of Toronto</author>
            

       
	            <media:content url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/life/health_wellness/2016/05/02/doctors-notes-your-mental-health-can-affect-your-heart-health/weight-gain.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg" medium="image">
	              <media:thumbnail url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/life/health_wellness/2016/05/02/doctors-notes-your-mental-health-can-affect-your-heart-health/weight-gain.jpg.size.xsmall.original.jpg"></media:thumbnail>
	              <media:description>Medication to improve mental health can often lead to weight gain, which in turn causes other problems.</media:description>
	              <media:credit role="author">Associated Press File Photo</media:credit>
	              
	              <media:credit role="owner"></media:credit>
	              
	            </media:content>
	            

        
        

        
        

        
        
        </item>
    
        <item>
          <title>Can air pollution increase weight gain?</title>
          <link>https://www.thestar.com/life/health_wellness/nutrition/2016/05/02/can-air-pollution-increase-weight-gain.html</link>
          <guid isPermaLink="false">04539a16-8d8c-4262-8731-51a73632ad03</guid>
          
          <pubDate>Mon, 2 May 2016 00:01:00 EDT</pubDate>
          <description>
          
          	<img src="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/life/2016/05/02/can-air-pollution-increase-weight-gain/pollution.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg"/><br/>A new, peer-reviewed study from China adds to the growing evidence suggesting that the quality of the air has a role in fat gain.
          
          </description>

          
          
          <author>
            Jennifer Sygo - Special to the Star</author>
            

       
	            <media:content url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/life/2016/05/02/can-air-pollution-increase-weight-gain/pollution.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg" medium="image">
	              <media:thumbnail url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/life/2016/05/02/can-air-pollution-increase-weight-gain/pollution.jpg.size.xsmall.original.jpg"></media:thumbnail>
	              <media:description>: A Chinese man and his child wear masks to protect against pollution as they walk through a shopping area in heavy smog on December 8, 2015 in Beijing, China. A new study from China suggest air pollution may contribute to weight gain.</media:description>
	              <media:credit role="author">Kevin Frayer</media:credit>
	              
	              <media:credit role="owner">GETTY IMAGES file photo</media:credit>
	              
	            </media:content>
	            

        
        

        
        

        
        
        </item>
    
        <item>
          <title>Scarborough and Durham to get new hospitals, minister says</title>
          <link>https://www.thestar.com/life/health_wellness/2016/04/28/scarborough-and-durham-to-get-new-hospitals-minister-says.html</link>
          <guid isPermaLink="false">d7aa8ac1-70a0-4f72-9cd3-f6b9f554f88a</guid>
          
          <pubDate>Thu, 28 Apr 2016 20:07:21 EDT</pubDate>
          <description>
          
          	<img src="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/life/health_wellness/2016/04/28/scarborough-and-durham-to-get-new-hospitals-minister-says/hospital.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg"/><br/>Health Minister Eric Hoskins has given the thumbs up to major hospital restructuring in the eastern GTA, which will also split up the Rouge Valley Health System.
          
          </description>

          
          
          <author>
            Theresa Boyle - Health, Ontario</author>
            

       
	            <media:content url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/life/health_wellness/2016/04/28/scarborough-and-durham-to-get-new-hospitals-minister-says/hospital.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg" medium="image">
	              <media:thumbnail url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/life/health_wellness/2016/04/28/scarborough-and-durham-to-get-new-hospitals-minister-says/hospital.jpg.size.xsmall.original.jpg"></media:thumbnail>
	              <media:description>The Scarborough Hospital campuses will grow under a new plan that would add the Centenary campus of the Rouge Valley Health System to the group, to form a new Scarborough Health Corporation.</media:description>
	              <media:credit role="author">AARON HARRIS</media:credit>
	              
	              <media:credit role="owner">TORONTO STAR</media:credit>
	              
	            </media:content>
	            

        
        

        
        

        
        
        </item>
    
        <item>
          <title>Memoir reveals bond between school bus driver and special needs passengers</title>
          <link>https://www.thestar.com/life/health_wellness/2016/04/28/memoir-reveals-bond-between-school-bus-driver-and-special-needs-passengers.html</link>
          <guid isPermaLink="false">893ee18a-0965-4d3e-bf53-c4b7c9021038</guid>
          
          <pubDate>Thu, 28 Apr 2016 13:00:00 EDT</pubDate>
          <description>
          
          	<img src="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/life/health_wellness/2016/04/28/memoir-reveals-bond-between-school-bus-driver-and-special-needs-passengers/craig-davidson3.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg"/><br/>In Precious Cargo, author Craig Davidson recounts a year driving children who made him laugh and cry and changed his life
          
          </description>

          
          
          <author>
            Andrea Gordon - Feature Writer</author>
            

       
	            <media:content url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/life/health_wellness/2016/04/28/memoir-reveals-bond-between-school-bus-driver-and-special-needs-passengers/craig-davidson3.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg" medium="image">
	              <media:thumbnail url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/life/health_wellness/2016/04/28/memoir-reveals-bond-between-school-bus-driver-and-special-needs-passengers/craig-davidson3.jpg.size.xsmall.original.jpg"></media:thumbnail>
	              <media:description>Author Craig Davidson spent a year driving a schoolbus for students with special needs. It opened his eyes and changed his attitude, as he reveals in his new book Precious Cargo.</media:description>
	              <media:credit role="author">J.P. MOCZULSKI</media:credit>
	              
	              <media:credit role="owner">The Toronto Star</media:credit>
	              
	            </media:content>
	            

        
        

        
        

        
        
        </item>

        <item>
          <title>Choosing cancer treatment based on celebs? You’re not alone, study suggests</title>
          <link>https://www.thestar.com/life/health_wellness/diseases_cures/2016/04/25/choosing-cancer-treatment-based-on-celebs-youre-not-alone-study-suggests.html</link>
          <guid isPermaLink="false">c6a21df3-3bb7-4774-84ff-b010bf8277ef</guid>
          
          <pubDate>Mon, 25 Apr 2016 09:00:00 EDT</pubDate>
          <description>
          
          	<img src="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/life/health_wellness/diseases_cures/2016/04/25/choosing-cancer-treatment-based-on-celebs-youre-not-alone-study-suggests/angelina-jolie.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg"/><br/>Research highlights how celebrity media coverage, such as Angelina Jolie’s story, may influence women to choose double mastectomy.
          
          </description>

          
          
          <author>
            Lauren Pelley - Staff Reporter</author>
            

       
	            <media:content url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/life/health_wellness/diseases_cures/2016/04/25/choosing-cancer-treatment-based-on-celebs-youre-not-alone-study-suggests/angelina-jolie.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg" medium="image">
	              <media:thumbnail url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/life/health_wellness/diseases_cures/2016/04/25/choosing-cancer-treatment-based-on-celebs-youre-not-alone-study-suggests/angelina-jolie.jpg.size.xsmall.original.jpg"></media:thumbnail>
	              <media:description>Angelina Jolie's 2013 op-ed about her preventative double mastectomy may have influenced more women to choose that option in the last few years.</media:description>
	              <media:credit role="author">Don Arnold</media:credit>
	              
	              <media:credit role="owner">WireImage</media:credit>
	              
	            </media:content>
	            

        
        

        
        

        
        
        </item>
